name: Pinzón Giant Tortoise
description: Pinzón tortoises are the smallest subspecies of Galápagos tortoises. They have long necks and saddle-shaped carapaces, adaptations to their grass-scarce native island, requiring them to stretch upward for food.
food_note: Leaves and fruits of prickly pears (opuntias) and other succulents
image_alt: Galápagos Tortoise, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
attractions: Active during the day except during the hottest hours, it tends to live solitarily.
projects_note: Once numbering over 250,000 across the Galápagos, these tortoises now survive in fewer than 12,000 adults due to historical hunting and introduced species.
